results.title: Together = Tillsammans [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Memfis, Lars Jonsson and Lukas Moodysson
results.brief_description: Together is a Swedish comedy written and directed by Lukas Moodysson (Fucking Amal aka Show me love). The setting is Stockholm, 1975, in the maelstrom of the counter culture movement. Elisabeth (Lisa Lindgren), a suburban housewife and mother of two, is leaving her abusive and alcoholic husband, Rolf (Michael Nygvist). Her choice of refuge is her brother’s commune where he is living with numerous adults, several couples and their children. The house is a hotbed of political thought, feminist ideals, sexual freedom and alternative thinking. Moodysson economically and amusingly depicts the tensions within the extended group and the complex, shifting relationships in the commune. The children in “Together” are realistically depicted, in particular Elisabeth’s children, Eva (Emma Samuelsson), a depressed and lonely teen, and Stefan (Sam Kessel), who longs for his father and a return to the nuclear family. Elisabeth’s brother Goran (Gustav Hammarsten) is the lynchpin of the house, a peacekeeper who aims to keep all members of the commune from warring with each other, despite his own woes with his partner, Lena. “Together” is a moving and funny tale of individuals, groups, couples, children, outsiders, swingers, ideologues, families, neighbours and friends. In Swedish with English subtitles.

results.title: Together [DVD]
results.creator_credit: 21st Century Hero Film Investment, Big Bang Creative, China Film Group Corporation, Chen Hong, Lee Joo-ik and Chen Kaige
results.brief_description: Returning to his native China, after the risible reception for his first English language feature, “Killing me softly” Chen Kaige treads on safe ground with this coming of age tale about a prodigious twelve-year-old violinist. Xiao Chun travels to Beijing seeking a place at a prestigious music academy, but after losing (unfairly, as it turns out, due to a lack of connections and payola), Xiao Chun’s father seeks private tuition with a cynical teacher fallen on hard times. Thus starts the journey of Xiao Chun into manhood; his talent grows as does his distraction for a flirtatious, (yet tender), prostitute who lives nearby. Introduced to the notions of love, honesty, deception and betrayal, Xiao Chun must soon choose between his gauche but loving country-bumpkin father and a cultured but soulless life in the city. Also available on VHS [318952].

results.title: Together
results.creator_credit: BFI, Lorenzo Mazzetti and Denis Horn
results.brief_description: The story of two deaf mutes who work on the docks and live together in a dingy lodging house. A study in isolation - influenced by the Italian neo-realist school. One of the first films of the British ‘Free Cinema’ movement.

results.title: Today in Britain
results.creator_credit: World Wide Pictures, James Carr and Peter Hopkinson
results.brief_description: Shows some of the many facets of life in Britain in 1964 and attempts to capture the spirit of the nation. It looks at developments in industry, atomic power, sport and education.

results.title: Today and tomorrow: a story of the Middle East
results.creator_credit: World Wide Pictures, Ralph Bond and Robin Carruthers
results.brief_description: This film deals with the impact of World War II on the precarious economies of the Middle East. It discusses the instability of pre-war Middle East, methods used by the Allies to avert famine during the war, and the desirability of continuing such measures in peacetime. Focuses on Egypt, its people and their lifestyles. Narrated by Valentine Dyall and Colin Wills.

results.title: Today's culture: options after high school
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Media and Henry Blinder
results.brief_description: It’s no longer a matter of go to college or go to work. Options have changed, and it’s up to the individual to find the lifestyle and education that fits the person’s need. Interviews with people who have found their niches both academically and non-academically show the wide range of opportunities now open.
